headline: Owls Fall in Four at Tulane
content: NEW ORLEANS – Florida Atlantic volleyball drops a four-setter, 3-1 (25-17, 26-24, 18-25, 25-20) to the Tulane Green Wave on the road Friday at Avron B. Fogelman Arena. The Owls fall to 17-9 on the season and 8-5 in American play, while Tulane moves to 11-13 overall and 3-10 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED Tulane took the opening lead, holding a 15-11 advantage through the first set media break. The Owls battled back to within three, cutting the deficit to 18-15 after a kill from Kierstin Bevelle, but FAU couldn't close out the rally as the Green Wave captured the set on a 7-2 run to take the opening set 25-17. The Owls opened the second set strong, taking the opening lead at 4-1 Tulane answered back, cutting the Owls' lead to one at 7-6, however, Kayla Richardson helped spark a 4-0 Owl run with a kill and a block assist, along with a pair of Green Wave attacking errors to extend FAU's lead back to five, 11-6, pushing the Green Wave to call their first timeout of the set. Tulane cut the deficit in half shortly after, forcing the Owls to call a timeout of their own, holding a 13-11 lead. The Green Wave battled, eventually bringing the set even at 19-19. The Owls maintained the lead, holding a 23-22 advantage, but the Green Wave had late set success with a 4-1 run to earn the second set win, 26-24, and a two-set lead. Tulane held the early advantage in the third, opening the frame on an 8-5 run. However, following an FAU timeout, the Owls locked in to outscore the Green Wave 11-3 and take a five-point advantage at 16-11. The Owls fought and closed out the third set on a 6-5 run, as Anna Hartman registered the kill to take the third, 25-18. FAU fell behind quickly to open the fourth with Tulane building an 11-2 lead to open the frame. However, the Owls scored five unanswered points, capped off by a Zoe Winford kill, to cut the lead to four, 11-7. FAU kept the set within four through a 19-15 Tulane advantage, but couldn't close the gap with the Green Wave taking the fourth 25-20 for the match win. STATS & NOTES Olivia Hart and Bevelle led the way for the Owls. Hart finished with a team-best 14 kills, notching her 11th double-double of the season with 13 digs, as well as tying for a team-high two blocks and adding a pair of aces. Bevelle joined Hart in double-figures with 11 kills and added two digs and a block in the match. Emsley Venard once again dished out a team-leading 20 assists. Isabelle Northam recorded a team-best 18 digs. As a team, the Owls held advantages over the Green Wave in kills (52), assists (50), and service aces (8). UP NEXT The Owls will look to bounce back on Sunday, Nov. 9, as they visit conference leader Rice for a 2 p.m. ET first serve inside Tudor Fieldhouse and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Take Homecoming Game Versus Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Behind three touchdowns from Easton Messer and three takeaways from the defense, the Florida Atlantic football team defeated Tulsa in Saturday afternoon's Homecoming game at Flagler Credit Union Stadium by a score of 40-21. The Owls (4-5, 3-3) dropped 40 points at home for the third time this season with a complete game on both sides of the ball against the Golden Hurricane (2-7, 0-6), winning the turnover margin battle 3-1. VIDEO RECAP THE BEGINNING Starting out on defense, redshirt senior DB Terez Reid picked off a pass on the fourth play of the game, the Owls' first interception of the year. FAU's first drive on offense culminated in a 39-yard field goal by Garrison Smith, extending its program record to six consecutive games with a score on the opening possession. After a goal-line stand on defense, redshirt junior QB Caden Veltkamp continued his growing connection with redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt, hitting him down the sideline where Platt took it 47 yards for a touchdown and a 10-0 lead. THE TURNING POINT Following two Tulsa field goals early in the second, Veltkamp found a wide-open Messer for a 44-yard score to up the score to 17-6, the first of 21 unanswered points to close the half. It was then redshirt senior DB Damarius McGhee's turn to make a game-changing play, scooping up a fumble at the goal line and returning it 95 yards for the score. With the defense back on the field, senior DB Chris Keys Jr. made an interception to give it right back to the Owls, setting up the second score to Messer on an 11-yard strike to send FAU to the locker room up 31-6. THE FINISH After a quiet third quarter, a drive commanded by graduate QB Zach Gibson gave the Owls 40. A 30-yard grab from Platt on 4th-and-one flea flicker set up Messer's nine-yard score, his third of the day. Two sacks – one by junior DE Deshaun Batiste and the other by freshman DE Josh Roberts – kept Tulsa out of the end zone the rest of the way. OFFENSE Messer's hat trick was the first multi-score game of his collegiate career. He becomes just the sixth receiver in program history to haul in three touchdown catches in a single game. For the second week in a row, Platt recorded a 100+ yard receiving game with 114 on five catches. Sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton logged the first 100+ yard game of his career, with 107 yards on just 11 carries. He ripped off a 50-yard run, the longest of his career, to end the first quarter. DEFENSE McGhee's 95-yard fumble return is the second longest in program history, yardage not seen since the second game in the 2001 inaugural season. Leading the way in tackles was redshirt junior Leon Hart Jr. with 12. Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky recorded 11 tackles, his fourth straight game in double digits. In addition to the three takeaways, the Owls' defensive unit forced three turnovers-on-downs, and recorded five sacks, eight tackles for loss and six pass breakups POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt Junior QB Caden Veltkamp Graduate QB Zach Gibson Redshirt Junior WR Easton Messer Redshirt Junior WR Jayshon Platt Graduate OL Alex Atcavage Redshirt Senior DB Terez Reid Redshirt Senior DB Damarius McGhee PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-8-2025) Tulsa at Florida Atlantic UP NEXT The Owls will travel for their final road game of the 2025 season, heading to New Orleans for a matchup with Tulane on Saturday, Nov. 15. Kickoff is at 4 p.m. ET on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Owls End the Night with Victory Over Charleston in Field of 68
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. – Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team opened up the Field of 68 Tip-Off with a wire-to-wire 94-77 victory over Charleston on Saturday evening at Liberty Arena. The Owls (2-0) jumped out to a double-digit lead over the Cougars (1-2) early and did not look back the rest of the way. In a typical balanced offensive showing under Head Coach John Jakus, six players scored in double figures, with all 13 who stepped onto the court recording points. FIRST HALF Like the previous game, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool opened scoring. Five straight points from redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams gave the Owls an early 12-3 lead, with a dunk from junior center Vincent Neugebauer putting the team ahead by double digits. The lead grew to as big as 19, with a late shot from junior guard Kanaan Carlyle sending the Owls to the locker room with a 48-32 advantage. Defensively, Florida Atlantic did not surrender a field goal to four Charleston starters, holding them to a combined 0-for-11 shooting. SECOND HALF Two triples from junior forward Xander Pintelon put Florida Atlantic up by 20 five minutes in the second half. The Owls then worked their way in the paint, with sophomore Maxim Logue connecting on four shots in a four-minute span. Florida Atlantic led by as much as 25 and reached the 90-point mark with a three-pointer from redshirt freshman Liam Dayco-Green in his collegiate debut. PRESS CONFERENCES STATS & NOTES The Owls made the most of their second chance opportunities, outscoring the Cougars 24-7. Florida Atlantic converted 11 shots behind the arc, their second straight game with 10+ to open the season. Carlyle led the team in scoring for the second game in a row, this time with 14. Logue shot a perfect six-for-six from the field. Vanterpool had another balanced statline, logging six rebounds and five assists. Three Owls recorded the first points of their collegiate careers: Neugebauer, redshirt freshman guards Amar Amkou, and Dayco-Green FAU holds a 4-1 record in the Field of 68 Tip-Off. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will close the Field of 68 Tip-Off, facing host team Liberty on Sunday, Nov. 9. Tipoff is at 6 p.m. on the Field of 68's YouTube channel. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Jackson’s Buzzer-Beater Seals Road Win at Kennesaw State
content: KENNESAW, Ga. – The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team moves to 2-0 on the season, notching Coach Freeland's first road win at Florida Atlantic with a 69-68 victory over Kennesaw State on Saturday at VyStar Arena. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls trailed for much of the first quarter before Michiyah Simmons tied it at 10 with 4:33 left to go in the first. The game began to pick up speed, going back and forth, ending the first quarter with Florida Atlantic leading 19-16 off a Destyne Jackson 3-pointer. FAU started the second quarter strong, extending their lead to 26-19 in the first two minutes. Kennesaw State cut the Florida Atlantic lead to three at 29-26 by the media timeout. Jackson put the Owls' lead back to six with 30 seconds remaining in the half. The Owls entered halftime with a 37-31 lead. To start the third quarter, Kennesaw State committed three team fouls, and the Owls' lead extended to 10, 41-31, within the first minute of play. KSU began to close the lead before a Grace Carstensen 3-pointer extended the lead back to seven. The Owls then gained their largest lead of the contest at the six-minute mark with the score standing at 51-40. FAU held its lead at nine through the end of the third, taking a 61-52 lead into the final 10 minutes of play. Kennesaw State made a run in the fourth quarter, keeping Florida Atlantic from scoring for over two minutes. The Owls' lead shrank to one point, sitting at 64-63 with 3:48 to go in the game. KSU took the lead with two minutes to go in the game before Jackson called game with a corner 3-pointer with two seconds left to capture the win, 69-68. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we played really well for the first three quarters, and then the fatigue set in a little bit, but I'm extremely proud of the fight and the grit to finish the game. Destyne's shot at the end of the fourth was huge. Just really proud of our team effort and our belief that we would pull it out." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Four Florida Atlantic players finished in double figures. Jackson with 13, Simmons with 12, Jess Moors with 11, and Carstensen with 10. Vivian Onugha led the team in rebounds on the night with four. Simmons had a team-leading five assists. The Owls were 50 percent from both field goal and 3-point range on the night, matching up well to Kennesaw State's 48.1 field goal percentage and 16.7 three-point percentage. UP NEXT The Owls head to Coral Gables to face Miami on Thursday, Nov. 13, at 7 p.m. inside the Watsco Center on ACC Network Extra. FOLLOW THE OWLS For updates, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Drop Three-Setter at Rice
content: HOUSTON – The Florida Atlantic Volleyball battled tough against conference leader Rice, but the Owls fell in three sets, 3-0 (25-20, 25-19, 26-24), on the road Sunday in Houston. The Owls fall to 17-10 overall and 8-6 in American play, while Rice moves to 17-8 on the season and 13-1 in league play. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls took the early lead 2-0, scoring back-to-back points off a kill from Anna Hartman and a Rice attacking error. Florida Atlantic maintained an advantage through a 10-9 lead after a Rice service error, however, Rice produced a 5-1 run to take its first lead of the set, 14-11. FAU scored three unanswered points off a pair of kills from Olivia Hart and Kayla Richardson, as well as a hitting error, but Rice retook the lead 15-14 at the first set media timeout. Out of the break, another Rice service error and a kill from Hart put the Owls back in front, 16-15. However, a 5-0 Rice run shifted the lead once again, 20-16, forcing a pair of timeouts from the Owls. Rice closed the set on a 5-4 run to take the opening 1-0 lead. After battling through a 9-9 stalemate to open set two, Rice scored nine unanswered points to break away to an 18-9 advantage. The Owls battled back, producing a 5-1 run to cut the deficit to five, 19-14, forcing Rice to call its first timeout of set two. However, the Owls couldn't muster another run as they traded points throughout the remainder of the set, as Rice eventually took the second set 25-19 for the two-set lead. FAU took the lead to open set three, holding an 11-9 advantage after a kill from Hartman and a block from Kierstin Bevelle and Libby Ashline. Rice retook the lead 14-12 after a 5-1 run, but FAU responded to take the lead back, eventually holding a 23-21 advantage. The Owls held set point at 24-23, but a service error and two attacking errors closed out the match as Rice took the set 26-24 to claim the three-set match. STATS & NOTES Hart and Hartman paced the Owls in the match, recording 11 and 10 kills, respectively. Emsley Venard dished out a team-high 17 assists across the three sets. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, recording a team-high 12 digs. Bevelle paced the Owls' block, tallying a team-best three blocks in the match. UP NEXT The Owls return home next week, hosting South Florida on Wednesday, Nov. 12, before closing the regular season against UTSA on Friday, Nov. 14, for Senior Day. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Defeated by Flames to Split Field of 68 Tip-Off
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. – The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team dropped the 2025 Field of 68 Tip-Off finale to Liberty by a score of 88-68 on Sunday evening. While the Flames (3-0) handed the Owls (2-1) their first loss of the season, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool impressed with a career high 24-point performance, shooting 10-for-15 from the field. FIRST HALF For the third game in a row, Vanterpool converted the first field goal make for the Owls for his first two of 10 points in the opening period. FAU kept the game within single digits for the first 12 minutes before surrendering a three-pointer to fall behind 31-19. Continuing to find success off offensive rebounds, Florida Atlantic outscored Liberty 13-2 on second chance points in the first half. The Owls closed a 20-point deficit with a 9-2 run before entering the locker room at halftime trailing 48-30. SECOND HALF Vanterpool continued where he left off with a three-pointer to open second-half scoring. He scored eight of the Owls' first nine points, including a three-point play. Junior guard Kanaan Carlyle attacked the hoop with all eight of his points coming in the final 20 minutes. PRESS CONFERENCE STATS & NOTES Vanterpool's 24 points doubles his previous career high of 12. Sophomore forward Maxim Logue made three out of his four field goal attempts. He finished the Field of 68 Tip-Off, shooting a combined nine-for-10 from the field. Redshirt freshman guard Amar Amkou scored a career-best eight points in six minutes of action. Florida Atlantic won the rebounding battle 34-28. The Owls outscored the Flames 11-2 on fastbreak points. UP NEXT The Owls will have a week off before returning to Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Monday, Nov. 17, for a meeting with Coastal Georgia. Tipoff is at 7 p.m. on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Owls Meet Tulsa in American Conference Semifinals
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Florida Atlantic men's soccer (10-3-2) will face Tulsa (5-8-4) in the American Conference Semifinals on Wednesday afternoon. Kickoff is set for 3:30 p.m. at Transamerica Field on the campus of Charlotte. ABOUT THE OWLS The Owls are back in the American Semifinals for the second time since joining the conference in 2022. The Owls are looking to earn their second conference tournament title (2007). Senior forward Mamadou Diarra is the American Conference Offensive Player of the Year. The Owls were also awarded Coaching Staff of the Year, and five players were named to the all-conference teams. Aboubacar Traore, Sebastian Zettl, and Diarra are all tied for third in program history with 15 assists for their respective careers. The record is 19. The Owls are looking to join the 2007, 2003, and 1989 teams with 11 wins in a season (3rd-most in a single season). 13 is the single-season record set by the 1996 team. ABOUT THE GOLDEN HURRICANE Tulsa knocked off USF 3-2 in overtime in the Quarterfinals. Redshirt sophomore midfielder Jared Aguilar leads the team with nine points. Tulsa finished sixth in the American in the regular season with a record of 3-3-2 in league play. SERIES HISTORY FAU and Tulsa tied 0-0 in the regular season finale on November 2. The Golden Hurricane lead the all-time series 4-0-1. WHAT'S NEXT The winner will face either Charlotte or FIU in the Championship on Saturday at 6 p.m. FOLLOW US For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Close Regular Season Against South Florida & UTSA
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic volleyball team will wrap up the regular season this week, hosting South Florida on Wednesday, Nov. 12, at 6 p.m., before welcoming UTSA for Senior Day on Friday, Nov. 14, at 6 p.m. at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. Fans can catch both matches live on ESPN+. A LOOK AT THE OWLS Florida Atlantic enters this week's matches sitting at sixth in the American at 17-10 overall and 8-6 in conference play. The Owls will look to bounce back after dropping a pair of road matches at Tulane, 3-1, and Rice, 3-0. The Owls' offensive leaders are Olivia Hart, Anna Hartman, and Erin Morrissey. Hart boasts a team-best 3.64 kills per set, while Hartman and Morrissey are averaging 2.71 and 2.41 kills per set, respectively. Florida Atlantic's offense is powered by assists leaders Emsley Venard and Victoria Hensley. Venard boasts a team-leading 574 assists, averaging 6.04 assists per set, while Hensley ranks second on the team with 485 assists, dishing out 5.05 assists per set. The Owls' back row leader is libero Isabelle Northam, boasting a team-best 388 digs, averaging 4.22 digs per set. Hart ranks second on the team in digs with 278, averaging 2.90 per set. At the net, Florida Atlantic's block is led by Maggie Allred, Kayla Richardson, and Libby Ashline. Allred has registered a team-best 101 blocks this season, averaging 1.13 blocks per set. Richardson ranks second with 62 blocks, averaging 0.67 blocks per set, while Ashline ranks third in blocks with 59, but second in blocks per set, averaging 0.92 blocks per set. SCOUTING SOUTH FLORIDA South Florida currently sits at second in the American and enters Wednesday's matchup at 15-10 overall and 11-3 in league play. The Bulls snapped a two-game losing streak this past Sunday, defeating Memphis in three sets. Offensively, the Bulls are led by Maria Clara Andrade, Laila Ivey, and Arianna Beckham. Andrade leads the team, averaging 4.31 kills per set, while Ivey and Beckham are averaging 2.48 and 2.41 kills per set, respectively. Raegan Richardson leads the team in assists, dishing out 821 assists this season, averaging 9.22 assists per set. Defensively, Samiha Foster paces the Bulls' back row, leading the team in digs, averaging 3.85 digs per set, while Imani Heartfield leads the USF block, recording a team-leading 0.86 blocks per set this season. SCOUTING UTSA UTSA currently ranks eighth in the American at 13-12 overall and 6-8 in conference play. The Roadrunners are on a two-match winning streak, earning a five-set win against Temple and a four-set win over Tulane this past weekend. Offensively, the Roadrunners are led by Ally Tribe, Gigi Mason, Taylor Gaines, and Caroline Tredwell. Tribe leads the team with 256 kills, recording 2.72 kills per set, while Mason, Gaines, and Tredwell are averaging 2.44, 2.29, and 2.27 kills per set, respectively. Megan Hawkins and Ilaria Durante lead UTSA in assists. Hawkins boasts a team-best 471 assists, averaging 5.18 assists per set, while Durante ranks second with 303 assists, averaging 3.99 assists per set. UTSA's back row is anchored by Giada Obregon, who leads the team with 305 digs, averaging 3.35 digs per set, while the Roadrunners' block is led by Miranda Putnicki and Tredwell, tallying 0.96 and 0.78 blocks per set, respectively. SERIES HISTORY Wednesday's midweek match marks the 24th matchup between the Owls and the Bulls. USF leads the series 18-5, including a 3-5 record when playing in Boca Raton. The Owls will look to snap a two-game skid against the Bulls, which includes a four-set loss earlier this season on Sept. 24 in Tampa. Friday's regular-season finale will be the 13th all-time meeting between Florida Atlantic and UTSA and the fifth meeting in Boca Raton. UTSA leads the series 11-1, including a 3-1 record when playing in Paradise. The Owls will look to snap a three-game skid against the Roadrunners. FAU's only win came on Nov. 1, 2019, when the Owls earned a straight-set sweep against the Roadrunners. In the last meeting between the two teams, UTSA took a three-set match last season on Nov. 10, 2024, in San Antonio. UP NEXT Following this week's matches, the Owls will start preparing for postseason play as they get ready to play in the American Volleyball Tournament on Friday, Nov. 21, through Sunday, Nov. 23, in Tampa, Florida. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: No Easy Task in the Big Easy
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic football team will head to New Orleans this Saturday, Nov. 15 for a matchup against American Conference contender Tulane, scheduled for 4 p.m. ET and airing on ESPN+ and Fox Sports 640 South Florida. The two teams will meet for the third time, second as American Conference members. The two first met back in Boca Raton in 2013 with the Owls coming away with a 34-17 win. The Owls then fell to a No. 24 Tulane, 24-8, also in Paradise, in 2023. NOTABLE Starting Fast - Hagerty Family Football Head Coach Zach Kittley's Air Raid offense is aggressive early and often, which has paid off tremendously. The Owls have scored on their opening possession in six consecutive games, never done before in program history. Since the month of October began, the offense converted 20 out of 23 (87%) fourth down attempts. Hat Tricks - Redshirt junior wide receiver Easton Messer had the first multi-touchdown game of his career in the 40-21, hauling in three scores. He is the second Owl to record a hat trick game of TDs, joining sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton who scored three on the ground versus UAB. This marks the first time since 2019 in which both a runner and a receiver have had a three-touchdown game for the Owls in one season. All-Around Platt - Redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt has recorded back-to-back 100+ yard games, now up to 585 receiving on the season. He also contributes to the Owls via kick return (498 yards) and rushing (12 yards per-carry, one touchdown). His 124.3 all-purpose yards per game ranks 10th nationwide. Elite Company - Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky has racked up tackles at a high rate, notching 12+ in four straight games. The last Owl to do so was Azeez Al-Shaair back in 2017. Stolsky holds the team lead at 72 through nine games. 100 Back-to-Back - Platt is the second wideout this season to have 100+ receiving yards in consecutive games, versus Navy and Tulsa. He joins Messer, who had 100+ against Memphis and Rice. They are the first duo in program history to have two consecutive games reaching the century mark in receiving yards. Strong Last Third - The Owls will face Tulane, UConn and ECU to close the 2025 regular season. The trio is a combined 20-8 on the year. Tuesday Media ESPN+ Click HERE to watch Coach Kittley's weekly press conference, joined by redshirt senior offensive lineman Scarlee Jean and redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky. headline: Kuhn Named ASUN Diver of the Week; Seventh Time in his Career
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – For the seventh time in his Florida Atlantic career, junior diver Trevor Kuhn has been named ASUN Diver of the Week after his performance at the South Florida Diving Invite, as announced by the conference on Tuesday. This is Kuhn's second honor of the 2025-26 season while making it a third time an Owl has won a diving weekly honor this season. Giving the Owls significant scoring in their victory over the weekend, Kuhn walked away from the meet with a pair of first-place finishes and one second-place finish. The winning began Friday on the platform where Kuhn won the event after totaling a final score of 287.50. During Saturday's springboard competition, he won the 1 mtr, finishing with a score of 305.60, then finishing his day with a runner-up finish on the 3 mtr. ON DECK The Owls will have a little bit over a month off before gearing up for the Patriot Midseason Invitational hosted by George Mason. The three-day meet begins on Thursday, Nov. 20 with competition wrapping up on Saturday, Nov. 22. FAU will be looking for a third consecutive team sweep of the meet. SCHEDULE For the full 2025-26 swim & dive schedule, click HERE. ROSTER For the full 2025-26 swim & dive roster, click HERE. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage from the meet and more FAU swimming & diving news, follow along on social media platforms (@fauswimdive).

headline: Florida Atlantic Coaches Show Presented by Duffy’s
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Florida Atlantic's Coaches Show, presented by Duffy's Sports Grill, returns Thursday, Nov. 13 at Duffy's Sports Grill of Boca Raton, located at 21212 St. Andrews Boulevard in Boca Raton. The show will air from 6-7 p.m. on Fox Sports 640 South Florida. Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley is the featured guest throughout the fall along with host and voice of the Owls Ken LaVicka. This week, Ends/Rush Coach Brandon Lacy will join the duo to talk about FAU's line growth throughout the year and the upcoming task of facing a dual threat quarterback on Saturday versus Tulane. To follow the games: football is scheduled to play at Tulsa at 4 p.m. on Saturday, Nov. 15 on ESPN+ and also will air on Fox Sports 640 AM South Florida. Come enjoy the Coaches Show while taking advantage of Duffy's famous 2-for-1 drinks, available all day, every day specials. The show also airs live each week on the flagship station of the Florida Atlantic Sports Network, FOX Sports 640 South Florida and the FOX Sports 640 app. CELEBRATING 25 YEARS Click HERE for 25 Years Celebration Content. COMPLETE 2025 SCHEDULE Click HERE. GROUPS OF ALL AGES To purchase group tickets, click HERE. FOLLOW THE TEAM Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through football's Twitter and Instagram accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Inside the Owls’ Burrow S10, EP14
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Florida Atlantic football celebrates its 25th season while FAU Athletics hits another milestone with Inside the Owls' Burrow in its 10th season showcasing all things FAU Athletics. Episode 14 of Inside the Owls' Burrow's 2025 football season, solely produced and hosted by Frank Forte, will air at 3 p.m., on Thursday, Nov. 13 where it will originate each week throughout the fall on FanDuel Sports Network Florida. It will re-air Saturday, Nov. 15 at 11:30 a.m. The weekly show's 14th installment of the fall will feature Forte talking one-on-one with first-year Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley about the Owls' homecoming win over Tulsa and this week's road battle at Tulane. Kickoff is scheduled for 4 p.m. ET and the game will air on ESPN+ and the local call will be on Fox Sports 640 AM South Florida. The show will also be a good opportunity to learn about redshirt freshman offensive lineman Keon Rohe's journey from Germany to American college football. This week's edition of "Pads Off" features redshirt junior Vincent Fiacable. Forte will also look back at 25 years of Owl football which features former quarterback Rusty Smith, the first Florida Atlantic player to be drafted into the NFL. Also learn about the impetus for FAU's "throwback" helmet, worn during the Tulsa game. SHOW TRAILER CELEBRATING 25 YEARS Click HERE for 25 Years Celebration Content. COMPLETE 2025 SCHEDULE Click HERE. GROUPS OF ALL AGES To purchase group tickets, click HERE. FOLLOW THE TEAM Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through football's Twitter and Instagram accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Onugha Garners American Honorable Mention Honors
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – After helping lead the Owls to a perfect 2-0 opening week, Florida Atlantic women's basketball forward Vivian Onugha was recognized as an American Conference Honorable Mention selection, as announced by the league office on Monday. The honor marks the first American weekly award for the Owls this season and Vivian's first career American honorable mention selection. Onugha had a strong opening week, leading the Owls to a pair of wins over Florida Memorial and Kennesaw State. Onugha finished the week with a team-leading 30 points, averaging 15 points per game, shooting 82 percent from the field (9-of-11) and finishing 12-for-21 at the line. She also collected a team second-best 15 boards, averaging 7.5 rebounds per game, in addition to adding two steals and a block in the Owls' two contests. Onugha opened the week with her first NCAA double-double, scoring a career-best 24 points, shooting 80% (8-of-10) from the field and going 8-of-13 from the line, while also collecting 11 boards, two steals, and a block vs. Florida Memorial. She closed out the week with six points in addition to pulling down four boards in the Owls' win at Kennesaw State. UP NEXT The Owls will continue their three-game road trek on Thursday, Nov. 13, as they head to Coral Gables to take on the Miami Hurricanes for a 7 p.m. tip on ACC Network Extra at the Watsco Center. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball

headline: Owls Versus Huskies Set for 3 p.m.
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Florida Atlantic football's game time on Saturday, Nov. 22 against UConn at Flagler Credit Union Stadium is scheduled for 3 p.m. on ESPN+, announced the American Conference on Monday. The Owls will take on the Huskies for the second straight season and third time in program history, but for the first time in Boca Raton. FAU is seeking its first win over UConn. While the 25th anniversary festivities will continue versus UConn, Florida Atlantic football will also celebrate the 300th game in program history and the 87th play at Flagler Credit Union Stadium, which opened in 2011. FOLLOW THE TEAM Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through football's Twitter and Instagram accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: McGhee and Messer Honored for Play
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Damarius McGhee and Easton Messer received Honorable Mention honors for their efforts in Florida Atlantic football's 40-21 victory over Tulsa last Saturday, announced the American Conference on Monday. McGhee, a redshirt senior CB from Pensacola, Florida, gathered a fumble forced by teammate Zyere Hortorn at the one-yard line and scampered 95 untouched yards for the second longest scoop and score in program history. The longest was 99 yards in the program's second game and first win back on September 8, 2001, 297 games between the two occurrences. McGhee was the first defensive score for the 2025 Owls and it put FAU up 17-6 with 58 seconds remaining in the first half. On the night, McGhee recorded five solo tackles, which was fourth on the team, and added a pass breakup. Messer, a WR from Louisville, Kentucky, completed his first career multi-TD game with three versus Tulsa. The redshirt junior etched himself in the FAU record book as the sixth player in program history to record three in one game. The slot receiver, who is No. 2 nationally with 8.22 catches per game, collected six passes last Saturday for a total of 83 yards, 34 coming after the catch. His longest of the game was a 44-yard TD reception that put the Owls up 10-6 over Tulsa with 5:21 remaining in the first. An 11-yard collection with 14 seconds remaining in the first half gave FAU a 24-6 lead heading into the break and he iced the game with a nine-yard reception thrown by Zach Gibson. The Owls will be back in action Saturday, Nov. 15 when they travel to New Orleans for a 4 p.m. ET contest versus Tulane. The game will air on ESPN+ and can be heard locally on Fox Sports 640 AM South Florida. CELEBRATING 2TH SEASON Click HERE for 25 Years Celebration Content. COMPLETE 2025 SCHEDULE Click HERE.
